abstract:
We prove that the depth of any arithmetic network for deciding membership in a semialgebraic set \({\Sigma \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}}\) is bounded from below by
$$c_1 \sqrt{ \frac{\log ({\rm b}(\Sigma))}{n}} -c_2 \log n,$$ where \({{\rm b}(\Sigma)}\) is the sum of the Betti numbers of \({\Sigma}\) with respect to “ordinary” (singular) homology, and c1, c2 are some (absolute) positive constants. This result complements the similar lower bound in Montaña et al. (Appl Algebra Engrg Comm Comput 7:41–51, 1996) for locally closed semialgebraic sets in terms of the sum of Borel–Moore Betti numbers.We also prove that if \({\rho: \mathbb{R}^{n} \to \mathbb{R}^{n-r}}\) is the projection map, for some \({r=0, \ldots, n}\), then the depth of any arithmetic network deciding membership in \({\Sigma}\) is bounded by
$$\frac{c_1\sqrt{\log ({\rm b}(\rho(\Sigma)))}}{n} - c_2 \log n$$for some positive constants c1, c2.
